1517    # -----------------------------------------------------------------------------     
1518    # zj add for semi-auto curve begin
1519    def autoCurve(self):
1520        """
1521        Generate tone curve automatically using machine learning analysis.
1522        
1523        Analyzes the current image's histogram distribution and uses a trained
1524        neural network to predict optimal control point values for enhanced
1525        image appearance. The ML model considers luminance distribution patterns
1526        to suggest appropriate tone mapping.
1527        
1528        The process involves:
1529        1. Computing cumulative histogram of image luminance
1530        2. Feeding histogram to trained neural network
1531        3. Predicting optimal control point values
1532        4. Applying the generated curve to the processing pipeline
1533        """
1534        processPipe = self.parent.controller.model.getProcessPipe()
1535        if processPipe != None :
1536            idExposure = processPipe.getProcessNodeByName("tonecurve")
1537            bins = np.linspace(0,1,50+1)
1538
1539            imageBeforeColorData = processPipe.processNodes[idExposure-1].outputImage.colorData
1540            imageBeforeColorData[imageBeforeColorData>1]=1
1541            imageBeforeY = colour.sRGB_to_XYZ(imageBeforeColorData, apply_cctf_decoding=False)[:,:,1]
1542            nphistBefore  = np.histogram(imageBeforeY, bins)[0]
1543            nphistBefore  = nphistBefore/np.amax(nphistBefore)
1544
1545            npImgHistCumuNorm = np.empty_like(nphistBefore)
1546            npImgHistCumu = np.cumsum(nphistBefore)
1547            npImgHistCumuNorm = npImgHistCumu/np.max(npImgHistCumu)
1548            
1549            #predict keypoint value
1550            if self.networkModel == None:
1551                self.networkModel = Net(50,5)
1552                self.networkModel.load_state_dict(torch.load(self.weightFile))
1553                self.networkModel.eval()
1554
1555            with torch.no_grad():
1556                x = Variable(torch.FloatTensor([npImgHistCumuNorm.tolist(),]), requires_grad=True)
1557                y_predict = self.networkModel(x)
1558
1559            kpc = (y_predict[0]*100).tolist() 
1560            kpcDict = {'start':[0.0,0.0], 'shadows': [10.0,int(kpc[0])], 'blacks': [30.0,int(kpc[1])], 'mediums': [50.0,int(kpc[2])], 'whites': [70.0,int(kpc[3])], 'highlights': [90.0,int(kpc[4])], 'end': [100.0,100.0]}
1561            self.setValues(kpcDict,callBackActive = True)
1562            self.parent.controller.changeToneCurve(kpcDict) 
1563     
1564    # zj add for semi-auto curve end   
1565
1566    # -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1567    def reset(self, key):
1568        """
1569        Reset specific control point to its default value.
1570        
1571        Restores a single control point to its default position and updates
1572        the curve accordingly. Useful for correcting individual control
1573        points without affecting the entire curve.
1574        
1575        Args:
1576            key (str): Control point to reset ('shadows', 'blacks', etc.)
1577        """
1578        if pref.verbose: print(" [CONTROL] >> ToneCurveController.reset(",key,") ")
1579
1580        valuesDefault = copy.deepcopy(self.model.default[key])[1]
1581        controls = self.model.setValue(key, valuesDefault)
1582        self.setValues(controls,callBackActive = False)
1583
1584        self.parent.controller.changeToneCurve(controls) 
1585    # -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1586    def plotCurve(self):
1587        """
1588        Display tone curve and histogram overlays.
1589        
1590        Renders the current tone curve along with optional histogram overlays

1593        
1594        The plot includes:
1595        - Grid lines for reference
1596        - Tone curve visualization
1597        - Control points markers
1598        - Optional histogram overlays for different processing stages
1599        """
1600        try:
1601            self.view.curve.plot([0,100],[0,100],'r--', clear=True)
1602            self.view.curve.plot([20,20],[0,100],'r--', clear=False)
1603            self.view.curve.plot([40,40],[0,100],'r--', clear=False)
1604            self.view.curve.plot([60,60],[0,100],'r--', clear=False)
1605            self.view.curve.plot([80,80],[0,100],'r--', clear=False)
1606
1607            processPipe = self.parent.controller.model.getProcessPipe()
1608            idExposure = processPipe.getProcessNodeByName("tonecurve")
1609
1610            bins = np.linspace(0,1,50+1)
1611
1612            if self.showInput:
1613                imageInput = copy.deepcopy(processPipe.getInputImage())
1614                if imageInput.linear: imageInputColorData =colour.cctf_encoding(imageInput.colorData, function='sRGB')
1615                else: imageInputColorData = imageInput.colorData
1616                imageInputColorData[imageInputColorData>1]=1
1617                imageInputY = colour.sRGB_to_XYZ(imageInputColorData, apply_cctf_decoding=False)[:,:,1]
1618                nphistInput  = np.histogram(imageInputY, bins)[0]
1619                nphistInput  = nphistInput/np.amax(nphistInput)
1620                self.view.curve.plot(bins[:-1]*100,nphistInput*100,'k--',  clear=False)
1621
1622            if self.showbefore:
1623                imageBeforeColorData = processPipe.processNodes[idExposure-1].outputImage.colorData
1624                imageBeforeColorData[imageBeforeColorData>1]=1
1625                imageBeforeY = colour.sRGB_to_XYZ(imageBeforeColorData, apply_cctf_decoding=False)[:,:,1]
1626                nphistBefore  = np.histogram(imageBeforeY, bins)[0]
1627                nphistBefore  = nphistBefore/np.amax(nphistBefore)
1628                self.view.curve.plot(bins[:-1]*100,nphistBefore*100,'b--',  clear=False)
1629
1630            if self.showAfter:
1631                imageAftercolorData = processPipe.processNodes[idExposure].outputImage.colorData
1632                imageAftercolorData[imageAftercolorData>1]=1
1633                imageAfterY  = colour.sRGB_to_XYZ(imageAftercolorData,  apply_cctf_decoding=False)[:,:,1]
1634                nphistAfter   = np.histogram(imageAfterY, bins)[0]
1635                nphistAfter   =nphistAfter/np.amax(nphistAfter)
1636                self.view.curve.plot(bins[:-1]*100,nphistAfter*100,'b',     clear=False)
1637
1638            if self.showOutput:
1639                imageAftercolorData = processPipe.getImage(toneMap=True).colorData
1640                imageAftercolorData[imageAftercolorData>1]=1
1641                imageAfterY  = colour.sRGB_to_XYZ(imageAftercolorData,  apply_cctf_decoding=False)[:,:,1]

1644                self.view.curve.plot(bins[:-1]*100,nphistAfter*100,'b',     clear=False)
1645
1646            controlPointCoordinates= np.asarray(list(self.model.control.values()))
1647            self.view.curve.plot(controlPointCoordinates[1:-1,0],controlPointCoordinates[1:-1,1],'ro', clear=False)
1648            points = np.asarray(self.model.curve.evalpts)
1649            x = points[:,0]
1650            self.view.curve.plot(points[x<100,0],points[x<100,1],'r',clear=False)
1651        except:
1652            time.sleep(0.5)
1653            self.plotCurve()

1531        3. Predicting optimal control point values
1532        4. Applying the generated curve to the processing pipeline
1533        """
1534        processPipe = self.parent.controller.model.getProcessPipe()
1535        if processPipe != None :
1536            idExposure = processPipe.getProcessNodeByName("tonecurve")
1537            bins = np.linspace(0,1,50+1)
1538
1539            imageBeforeColorData = processPipe.processNodes[idExposure-1].outputImage.colorData
1540            imageBeforeColorData[imageBeforeColorData>1]=1
1541            imageBeforeY = colour.sRGB_to_XYZ(imageBeforeColorData, apply_cctf_decoding=False)[:,:,1]
1542            nphistBefore  = np.histogram(imageBeforeY, bins)[0]
1543            nphistBefore  = nphistBefore/np.amax(nphistBefore)
1544
1545            npImgHistCumuNorm = np.empty_like(nphistBefore)
1546            npImgHistCumu = np.cumsum(nphistBefore)
1547            npImgHistCumuNorm = npImgHistCumu/np.max(npImgHistCumu)
1548            
1549            #predict keypoint value
1550            if self.networkModel == None:
1551                self.networkModel = Net(50,5)
1552                self.networkModel.load_state_dict(torch.load(self.weightFile))
1553                self.networkModel.eval()
1554
1555            with torch.no_grad():
1556                x = Variable(torch.FloatTensor([npImgHistCumuNorm.tolist(),]), requires_grad=True)
1557                y_predict = self.networkModel(x)
1558
1559            kpc = (y_predict[0]*100).tolist() 
1560            kpcDict = {'start':[0.0,0.0], 'shadows': [10.0,int(kpc[0])], 'blacks': [30.0,int(kpc[1])], 'mediums': [50.0,int(kpc[2])], 'whites': [70.0,int(kpc[3])], 'highlights': [90.0,int(kpc[4])], 'end': [100.0,100.0]}
1561            self.setValues(kpcDict,callBackActive = True)
1562            self.parent.controller.changeToneCurve(kpcDict)

Generate tone curve automatically using machine learning analysis.

Analyzes the current image's histogram distribution and uses a trained neural network to predict optimal control point values for enhanced image appearance. The ML model considers luminance distribution patterns to suggest appropriate tone mapping.

The process involves:

  1. Computing cumulative histogram of image luminance
  2. Feeding histogram to trained neural network
  3. Predicting optimal control point values
  4. Applying the generated curve to the processing pipeline

1738class HDRviewerController():
1739    """
1740    Controller for external HDR display and viewer management.
1741    
1742    This class manages the external HDR display functionality, coordinating with
1743    HDR-capable monitors to show processed images at their full dynamic range.
1744    It handles display process management, image comparison modes, auto-preview
1745    functionality, and HDR display scaling.
1746    
1747    The HDR viewer enables real-time preview of processing results on calibrated
1748    HDR displays, providing immediate visual feedback for professional HDR
1749    image editing workflows.
1750    
1751    Attributes:
1752        - parent: Parent controller for coordination
1753        - model (model.HDRviewerModel): HDR display data model
1754        - view: View component (set externally)

1756    """

1783    def callBackUpdate(self):
1784        """
1785        Update HDR display with the current processed image.
1786        
1787        Retrieves the currently selected processing pipeline, processes the
1788        image without tone mapping (preserving HDR values), and displays
1789        the result on the HDR monitor. Updates the current image reference
1790        for comparison operations.
1791        """
1792        selectedProcessPipe = self.parent.view.imageGalleryController.model.getSelectedProcessPipe()
1793        img = selectedProcessPipe.getImage(toneMap = False)
1794        self.displayIMG(img)
1795        self.model.currentIMG = img
1796
1797    def callBackAuto(self,on_off):
1798        """
1799        Toggle automatic HDR preview updates.
1800        
1801        Enables or disables automatic HDR display updates when processing
1802        parameters change, allowing for real-time preview on HDR monitors.
1803        
1804        Args:
1805            on_off (bool): Enable (True) or disable (False) auto-preview
1806        """
1807        self.parent.view.dock.view.childControllers[0].model.autoPreviewHDR = on_off
1808
1809    def callBackCompare(self):
1810        """
1811        Display before/after comparison on HDR monitor.
1812        
1813        Creates a side-by-side comparison showing the previous processing
1814        result alongside the current result, enabling visual comparison
1815        of processing changes. If no previous result exists, updates
1816        with current processing.
1817        """
1818        if self.model.currentIMG:
1819            old = self.model.currentIMG
1820            old = old.process(hdrCore.processing.clip())
1821
1822            sp = self.parent.view.imageGalleryController.model.getSelectedProcessPipe()
1823            img = sp.getImage(toneMap = False)
1824            img = img.process(hdrCore.processing.clip())
1825
1826
1827            h1, w1, _ = old.colorData.shape
1828            h2, w2, _ = img.colorData.shape
1829            hD, wD = self.model.displayModel['shape']
1830            hM = int((hD - max(h1,h2))/2)
1831            wM = int((wD - (w1+w2))/3)
1832            back =  np.ones((hD,wD,3))*0.2
1833
1834            back[hM:hM+h1,wM:wM+w1,:] = old.colorData*self.model.displayModel['scaling']
1835            back[hM:hM+h2,2*wM+w1:2*wM+w1+w2,:] = img.colorData*self.model.displayModel['scaling']
1836
1837            # save as temp.hdr
1838            colour.write_image(back,'temp.hdr', method='Imageio')
1839            self.displayFile('temp.hdr')
1840
1841            self.model.currentIMG = img
1842        else: self.callBackUpdate()
1843
1844    def displayFile(self, HDRfilename):
1845        """
1846        Display HDR file on external HDR monitor.
1847        
1848        Launches or updates the external HDR viewer process to display the
1849        specified HDR file. Handles process management and error recovery
1850        for reliable HDR display functionality.
1851        
1852        Args:
1853            HDRfilename (str): Path to HDR file to display
1854            
1855        Note:
1856            Uses HDRImageViewer.exe for Windows-based HDR display.
1857            Includes automatic process restart if initial launch fails.
1858        """
1859
1860         # check that no current display process already open
1861        if self.viewerProcess:
1862            # the display HDR process is already running
1863            # close current
1864            subprocess.run(['taskkill', '/F', '/T', '/IM', "HDRImageViewer*"],capture_output=False)
1865            time.sleep(0.05)
1866        # run display HDR process
1867        self.viewerProcess = subprocess.Popen(["HDRImageViewer.exe","-f", "-input:"+HDRfilename, "-f", "-h"], shell=True)
1868        time.sleep(0.10)
1869        psData = subprocess.run(['tasklist'], capture_output=True, universal_newlines=True).stdout
1870        if not 'HDRImageViewer' in psData: 
1871            # re-run display HDR process
1872            self.viewerProcess = subprocess.Popen(["HDRImageViewer.exe","-f", "-input:"+HDRfilename, "-f", "-h"], shell=True)
1873
1874    def displayIMG(self, img):
1875        """
1876        Display processed image on HDR monitor.
1877        
1878        Processes and displays a uHDR Image object on the external HDR monitor,
1879        applying appropriate clipping, scaling, and centering for optimal
1880        HDR display presentation.
1881        
1882        Args:
1883            img (hdrCore.image.Image): Processed HDR image to display
1884        """
1885        img = img.process(hdrCore.processing.clip())
1886        print(self.model.scaling())
1887        colorData = img.colorData*self.model.displayModel['scaling']
1888
1889        h,w, _ = colorData.shape
1890        hD, wD = self.model.displayModel['shape']
1891
1892        if w<wD:
1893            back = np.ones((hD,wD,3))*0.2
1894            marginW = int((wD-w)/2)
1895            marginH = int((hD-h)/2)
1896
1897            back[marginH:marginH+h,marginW:marginW+w,:]=colorData
1898
1899        # save as temp.hdr
1900        colour.write_image(back,'temp.hdr', method='Imageio')
1901        self.displayFile('temp.hdr')
1902
1903    def displaySplash(self):
1904        """
1905        Display default splash screen on HDR monitor.
1906        
1907        Shows the default splash screen image, typically used when no
1908        specific image is being displayed or during application startup.
1909        Clears the current image reference.
1910        """
1911        self.model.currentIMG = None
1912        self.displayFile('grey.hdr')

1921        """
1922        # check that no current display process already open

1924            # the display HDR process is already running
1925            # close current
1926            subprocess.run(['taskkill', '/F', '/T', '/IM', "HDRImageViewer*"],capture_output=False)
1927            self.viewerProcess = None

1809    def callBackCompare(self):
1810        """
1811        Display before/after comparison on HDR monitor.
1812        
1813        Creates a side-by-side comparison showing the previous processing
1814        result alongside the current result, enabling visual comparison
1815        of processing changes. If no previous result exists, updates
1816        with current processing.
1817        """
1818        if self.model.currentIMG:
1819            old = self.model.currentIMG
1820            old = old.process(hdrCore.processing.clip())
1821
1822            sp = self.parent.view.imageGalleryController.model.getSelectedProcessPipe()
1823            img = sp.getImage(toneMap = False)
1824            img = img.process(hdrCore.processing.clip())
1825
1826
1827            h1, w1, _ = old.colorData.shape
1828            h2, w2, _ = img.colorData.shape
1829            hD, wD = self.model.displayModel['shape']
1830            hM = int((hD - max(h1,h2))/2)
1831            wM = int((wD - (w1+w2))/3)
1832            back =  np.ones((hD,wD,3))*0.2
1833
1834            back[hM:hM+h1,wM:wM+w1,:] = old.colorData*self.model.displayModel['scaling']
1835            back[hM:hM+h2,2*wM+w1:2*wM+w1+w2,:] = img.colorData*self.model.displayModel['scaling']
1836
1837            # save as temp.hdr
1838            colour.write_image(back,'temp.hdr', method='Imageio')
1839            self.displayFile('temp.hdr')
1840
1841            self.model.currentIMG = img
1842        else: self.callBackUpdate()

Display before/after comparison on HDR monitor.

Creates a side-by-side comparison showing the previous processing result alongside the current result, enabling visual comparison of processing changes. If no previous result exists, updates with current processing.

def displayFile(self, HDRfilename): 
1844    def displayFile(self, HDRfilename):
1845        """
1846        Display HDR file on external HDR monitor.
1847        
1848        Launches or updates the external HDR viewer process to display the
1849        specified HDR file. Handles process management and error recovery
1850        for reliable HDR display functionality.
1851        
1852        Args:
1853            HDRfilename (str): Path to HDR file to display
1854            
1855        Note:
1856            Uses HDRImageViewer.exe for Windows-based HDR display.
1857            Includes automatic process restart if initial launch fails.
1858        """
1859
1860         # check that no current display process already open
1861        if self.viewerProcess:
1862            # the display HDR process is already running
1863            # close current
1864            subprocess.run(['taskkill', '/F', '/T', '/IM', "HDRImageViewer*"],capture_output=False)
1865            time.sleep(0.05)
1866        # run display HDR process
1867        self.viewerProcess = subprocess.Popen(["HDRImageViewer.exe","-f", "-input:"+HDRfilename, "-f", "-h"], shell=True)
1868        time.sleep(0.10)
1869        psData = subprocess.run(['tasklist'], capture_output=True, universal_newlines=True).stdout
1870        if not 'HDRImageViewer' in psData: 
1871            # re-run display HDR process
1872            self.viewerProcess = subprocess.Popen(["HDRImageViewer.exe","-f", "-input:"+HDRfilename, "-f", "-h"], shell=True)

def displayIMG(self, img): 
1874    def displayIMG(self, img):
1875        """
1876        Display processed image on HDR monitor.
1877        
1878        Processes and displays a uHDR Image object on the external HDR monitor,
1879        applying appropriate clipping, scaling, and centering for optimal
1880        HDR display presentation.
1881        
1882        Args:
1883            img (hdrCore.image.Image): Processed HDR image to display
1884        """
1885        img = img.process(hdrCore.processing.clip())
1886        print(self.model.scaling())
1887        colorData = img.colorData*self.model.displayModel['scaling']
1888
1889        h,w, _ = colorData.shape
1890        hD, wD = self.model.displayModel['shape']
1891
1892        if w<wD:
1893            back = np.ones((hD,wD,3))*0.2
1894            marginW = int((wD-w)/2)
1895            marginH = int((hD-h)/2)
1896
1897            back[marginH:marginH+h,marginW:marginW+w,:]=colorData
1898
1899        # save as temp.hdr
1900        colour.write_image(back,'temp.hdr', method='Imageio')
1901        self.displayFile('temp.hdr')

2052        """
2053        Set all color editing parameters programmatically.
2054        
2055        Updates all selection and editing controls simultaneously, typically
2056        used when loading saved color editing presets or initializing the

2061                          selection ranges and editing parameters

2069        self.view.sliderHueMin.setValue(int(v[0]))
2070        self.view.sliderHueMax.setValue(int(v[1]))
2071
2072        # slider chroma selection
2073        v = values['selection']['chroma'] if 'chroma' in values['selection'].keys() else (0,100)
2074        self.view.sliderChromaMin.setValue(int(v[0]))
2075        self.view.sliderChromaMax.setValue(int(v[1]))
2076
2077        # slider lightness
2078        v = values['selection']['lightness'] if 'lightness' in values['selection'].keys() else (0,100)
2079        self.view.sliderLightMin.setValue(int(v[0]*3))
2080        self.view.sliderLightMax.setValue(int(v[1]*3))
2081
2082        # hue shift editor
2083        v = values['edit']['hue'] if 'hue' in values['edit'].keys() else 0
2084        self.view.sliderHueShift.setValue(int(v))
2085        self.view.valueHueShift.setText(str(v)) 
2086
2087        # exposure editor
2088        v : int = values['edit']['exposure'] if 'exposure' in values['edit'].keys() else 0
2089        self.view.sliderExposure.setValue(int(v*30))
2090        self.view.valueExposure.setText(str(v)) 
2091
2092        # contrast editor
2093        v : int = values['edit']['contrast'] if 'contrast' in values['edit'].keys() else 0
2094        self.view.sliderContrast.setValue(int(v))
2095        self.view.valueContrast.setText(str(v))  
2096
2097        # saturation editor
2098        v : int = values['edit']['saturation'] if 'saturation' in values['edit'].keys() else 0
2099        self.view.sliderSaturation.setValue(int(v))
2100        self.view.valueSaturation.setText(str(v))  
2101
2102        # mask
2103        v : bool = values['mask'] if 'mask' in values.keys() else False
2104        self.view.checkboxMask.setChecked(values['mask'])             
2105
2106        self.model.setValues(values)
2107
2108        self.callBackActive = True

2161

2163        - parent: Parent controller for coordination

2178        self.view =     view.GeometryView(self)
2179

2182    def sliderCroppingVerticalAdjustementChange(self,v):
2183        """
2184        Handle vertical cropping position adjustments.
2185        
2186        Adjusts the vertical position of the crop area, allowing users to
2187        reframe the image vertically while maintaining the aspect ratio.
2188        
2189        Args:
2190            v (float): Vertical adjustment value (typically -100 to +100)
2191        """
2192        values = self.model.setCroppingVerticalAdjustement(v)
2193        if self.callBackActive : self.parent.controller.changeGeometry(values)
2194
2195    def sliderRotationChange(self,v):
2196        """
2197        Handle rotation angle adjustments.
2198        
2199        Adjusts the image rotation angle for correcting tilted horizons or
2200        perspective issues. Rotation is applied with automatic cropping to
2201        maintain rectangular output.
2202        
2203        Args:
2204            v (float): Rotation angle in degrees
2205        """
2206        values = self.model.setRotation(v)
2207        if self.callBackActive : self.parent.controller.changeGeometry(values)
2208
2209    def setValues(self, values, callBackActive = False):
2210        """
2211        Set all geometry parameters programmatically.
2212        
2213        Updates all geometric transformation controls simultaneously, typically
2214        used when loading saved geometry settings or batch updates.
2215        
2216        Args:
2217            values (dict): Dictionary containing geometry parameters including
2218                          'up' (vertical adjustment) and 'rotation' (angle)
2219            callBackActive (bool, optional): Whether to trigger callbacks (default: False)
2220        """
2221        if pref.verbose: print(" [CONTROL] >> GeometryController.setValue(",values,") ")
2222
2223        up =        values['up']        if 'up' in values.keys()        else 0.0
2224        rotation =  values['rotation']  if 'rotation' in values.keys()  else 0.0
2225
2226        self.callBackActive = callBackActive
2227
2228        self.view.sliderCroppingVerticalAdjustement.setValue(int(up))
2229        self.view.sliderRotation.setValue(int(rotation*6))
2230       
2231        self.model.setValues(values)
2232
2233        self.callBackActive = True

The geometry controller handles precision adjustments that are critical for professional HDR photography, especially when correcting architectural photography or adjusting horizon lines.

class ColorEditorsAutoController: 
2349class  ColorEditorsAutoController:
2350    """
2351    Controller for automatic color editor configuration and management.
2352    
2353    This class provides automated color editing capabilities by analyzing image
2354    content and automatically configuring multiple color editor instances with
2355    optimal settings. It uses advanced algorithms to identify dominant colors
2356    and suggest appropriate editing parameters for professional color grading.
2357    
2358    The automatic color editor system streamlines the workflow for complex color
2359    corrections by providing intelligent starting points for manual fine-tuning.
2360    
2361    Attributes:
2362        - parent: Parent controller for coordination
2363        - controlled (list): List of controlled color editor instances
2364        - stepName (str): Processing step name for this auto-controller
2365        - model (model.ColorEditorsAutoModel): Auto-color editing data model
2366        - view (view.ColorEditorsAutoView): Auto-color editing interface
2367        - callBackActive (bool): Enable/disable callback processing
2368    """
2369    def __init__(self, parent, controlledColorEditors, stepName ):
2370        """
2371        Initialize the automatic color editors controller.
2372        
2373        Args:
2374            parent: Parent controller for coordination
2375            controlledColorEditors (list): List of color editor controllers to manage
2376            stepName (str): Processing step identifier for this auto-controller
2377        """
2378        if pref.verbose: print(" [CONTROL] >> ColorEditorsAutoController.__init__(",") ")
2379
2380        self.parent = parent
2381        self.controlled = controlledColorEditors
2382        self.stepName =stepName
2383
2384        self.model =    model.ColorEditorsAutoModel(self, stepName,len(controlledColorEditors), removeBlack= True)
2385        self.view =     view.ColorEditorsAutoView(self)
2386
2387        self.callBackActive = True
2388    # callbacks
2389    def auto(self): 
2390        """
2391        Trigger automatic color editor configuration.
2392        
2393        Analyzes the current image to identify dominant colors and automatically
2394        configures all controlled color editors with appropriate selection ranges
2395        and initial editing parameters. Resets all editors before applying new
2396        automatic configurations.
2397        """
2398        if pref.verbose: print(" [CONTROL] >> ColorEditorsAutoController.auto(",") ")
2399        for ce in self.controlled: ce.resetSelection(); ce.resetEdit()
2400        values = self.model.compute()
2401
2402        if values != None:
2403            for i,v in enumerate(values): self.controlled[i].setValues(v, callBackActive = False)

This class provides automated color editing capabilities by analyzing image content and automatically configuring multiple color editor instances with optimal settings. It uses advanced algorithms to identify dominant colors and suggest appropriate editing parameters for professional color grading.

The automatic color editor system streamlines the workflow for complex color corrections by providing intelligent starting points for manual fine-tuning.
